Notes
Changes to cycle 2 (exam) assessment to meet changes in school policy. Removal of short answer questions and replacement with MCQs

Overview

Overview
Oikos is the Greek word meaning ‘the place in which we live’. Ecology, derived from this, is the study of the place in which we live, our natural environment. Ecological questions include understanding the pattern of where organisms are in space and time, how they disperse or move, the ways in which populations go up and down in size, how different species affect each other, how communities assemble over time, and how different ecosystems form and function. Evolutionary ecology is the study of why species have come to vary in biology in this natural environment context through the process of adaptation - why some animals live fast and die young, why some plants live for a year and others for 5000. In this course we will introduce our natural environment from why species vary in fundamental characteristics such as age at maturity and offspring production, to the threats facing natural populations and ecosystems on our changing planet.

The module will be delivered through research connected interactive lectures, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool. The two module assessments are designed to help students interpret scientific publications and online tests examine student knowledge and understanding of the topics they cover.
Educational Aims
Introduce how the approach of evolutionary ecology can help us understand how and why plant and animal species differ in movement patterns, dispersal, life history and dynamics

Introduce population ecology and the diversity and importance of interspecific interactions in the dynamics and evolution of populations and communities, including the importance of microbes in community function.

Establish the main ecosystems on earth and drivers of ecosystem diversity, and an understanding of the current challenges facing biodiversity and how we might address them on a global scale.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Ecology explores the intricacies of our living environment, encompassing the spatial and temporal distribution of organisms, their dispersal patterns, population dynamics, interspecies interactions, community development over time, and the formation and functioning of diverse ecosystems. Evolutionary ecology explores the biological variations among species within this natural context, examining phenomena like rapid life cycles or long lifespans. This course provides a comprehensive overview of both foundational ecology and evolutionary ecology, addressing the challenges that natural populations and ecosystems face in our dynamic world.

The module will be delivered through, research-connected lectures by research active scientists. There are two assessments which assess students in interpreting scientific publications, while online tests assess their grasp of the covered topics. These assessments collectively contribute to evaluating students' knowledge and understanding of the subject matter.
Outline Syllabus
1. Evolutionary ecology of the pace of life, including metabolic rate, body size, age at maturity, reproductive output/timing, senescence, and ageing.

2. Evolutionary ecology of spatial patterns: dispersal biology, landscape effects, migration, and social living.

3. Population growth and dynamics, including intraspecific competition. Problems of small populations.

4. The diversity, importance, ecological and evolutionary impacts of interspecific interactions.

5. Introduction to community ecology, including succession and microbial contribution to communities.

6. The major ecosystems and drivers of ecosystem diversity. Human impacts on ecosystems.

7. Threats to populations, communities and ecosystems and conservation practice.

Material will be taxonomically broad, and include microbial, plant and animal case studies wherever possible. Basic mathematical underpinnings to be outlined in principle. Interpreting ecological data is a key element of each element, as are the citizenship aspects of ecological understanding. Supporting material (for example papers) will be supplied on CANVAS, and the course will reference the core year 1 Biology text.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

Online Preparatory Material:

This is the form of online reading, videos, and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming lectures delivered through the VLE.

Lectures:

The module will be taught through lectures with a strong element of student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a four week period.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Independent learning time (120 hours) encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

A typical week would involve 6/7 teaching sessions; sessions would vary from lectures with embedded short exercises to sessions with a series of cases studies examined and commented on in student-led discussion, using polleverywhere and other means of engagement. These student-led elements would particularly focus elements such as global citizenship and ethical aspects of ecology that are strongly motivating for engagement. Each session would be supported by external reading, and a series of case studies/problems to solve, particularly involving data.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests requires students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.

Summative assessment

There are two assessments:

a) Mid-module assessment: Mixed Multiple choice and Matching answer questions covering the material covered in the first 14 contact sessions, including questions relating to data. (30% total)

b) End of module assessment with Multiple choice questions (70% total). A fraction of these are expected to include data interpretation. Questions will be biased to the final elements of the course (70% of questions from the second half of the course).

The data interpretation aspect of the assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will use the same format, but the questions and data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity exists.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE (Virtual Learning Environment) and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

BIOS104
Notes
Changes to cycle 2 (exam) assessment to meet changes in school policy. Removal of short answer questions and replacement with MCQs

Overview

Overview
Oikos is the Greek word meaning ‘the place in which we live’. Ecology, derived from this, is the study of the place in which we live, our natural environment. Ecological questions include understanding the pattern of where organisms are in space and time, how they disperse or move, the ways in which populations go up and down in size, how different species affect each other, how communities assemble over time, and how different ecosystems form and function. Evolutionary ecology is the study of why species have come to vary in biology in this natural environment context through the process of adaptation - why some animals live fast and die young, why some plants live for a year and others for 5000. In this course we will introduce our natural environment from why species vary in fundamental characteristics such as age at maturity and offspring production, to the threats facing natural populations and ecosystems on our changing planet.

The module will be delivered through research connected interactive lectures, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool. The two module assessments are designed to help students interpret scientific publications and online tests examine student knowledge and understanding of the topics they cover.
Educational Aims
Introduce how the approach of evolutionary ecology can help us understand how and why plant and animal species differ in movement patterns, dispersal, life history and dynamics

Introduce population ecology and the diversity and importance of interspecific interactions in the dynamics and evolution of populations and communities, including the importance of microbes in community function.

Establish the main ecosystems on earth and drivers of ecosystem diversity, and an understanding of the current challenges facing biodiversity and how we might address them on a global scale.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Ecology explores the intricacies of our living environment, encompassing the spatial and temporal distribution of organisms, their dispersal patterns, population dynamics, interspecies interactions, community development over time, and the formation and functioning of diverse ecosystems. Evolutionary ecology explores the biological variations among species within this natural context, examining phenomena like rapid life cycles or long lifespans. This course provides a comprehensive overview of both foundational ecology and evolutionary ecology, addressing the challenges that natural populations and ecosystems face in our dynamic world.

The module will be delivered through, research-connected lectures by research active scientists. There are two assessments which assess students in interpreting scientific publications, while online tests assess their grasp of the covered topics. These assessments collectively contribute to evaluating students' knowledge and understanding of the subject matter.
Outline Syllabus
1. Evolutionary ecology of the pace of life, including metabolic rate, body size, age at maturity, reproductive output/timing, senescence, and ageing.

2. Evolutionary ecology of spatial patterns: dispersal biology, landscape effects, migration, and social living.

3. Population growth and dynamics, including intraspecific competition. Problems of small populations.

4. The diversity, importance, ecological and evolutionary impacts of interspecific interactions.

5. Introduction to community ecology, including succession and microbial contribution to communities.

6. The major ecosystems and drivers of ecosystem diversity. Human impacts on ecosystems.

7. Threats to populations, communities and ecosystems and conservation practice.

Material will be taxonomically broad, and include microbial, plant and animal case studies wherever possible. Basic mathematical underpinnings to be outlined in principle. Interpreting ecological data is a key element of each element, as are the citizenship aspects of ecological understanding. Supporting material (for example papers) will be supplied on CANVAS, and the course will reference the core year 1 Biology text.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

Online Preparatory Material:

This is the form of online reading, videos, and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming lectures delivered through the VLE.

Lectures:

The module will be taught through lectures with a strong element of student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a four week period.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Independent learning time (120 hours) encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

A typical week would involve 6/7 teaching sessions; sessions would vary from lectures with embedded short exercises to sessions with a series of cases studies examined and commented on in student-led discussion, using polleverywhere and other means of engagement. These student-led elements would particularly focus elements such as global citizenship and ethical aspects of ecology that are strongly motivating for engagement. Each session would be supported by external reading, and a series of case studies/problems to solve, particularly involving data.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests requires students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.

Summative assessment

There are two assessments:

a) Mid-module assessment: Mixed Multiple choice and Matching answer questions covering the material covered in the first 14 contact sessions, including questions relating to data. (30% total)

b) End of module assessment with Multiple choice questions (70% total). A fraction of these are expected to include data interpretation. Questions will be biased to the final elements of the course (70% of questions from the second half of the course).

The data interpretation aspect of the assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will use the same format, but the questions and data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity exists.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE (Virtual Learning Environment) and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Examine the causes and consequences of variation in pace of life/life history observed between species in nature.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO2 Relate factors that impact population size and understand extinction threats arising from small populations.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO3 Explain the ways different species interact with each other and the consequences of these interactions for population size and persistence, and for evolution.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO4 Relate how ecological communities assemble and change over time.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO5 Discuss the major ecosystems in nature, their physical properties, and biological/geographical underpinnings, and how they change through time and through human activity, and describe the major threats to these
University of Liverpool · Semester 2

The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

In Programmes:Marine Biology BSc (Hons) 2025-26
Marine Biology BSc (Hons) 2025-26
Evolutionary Anthropology BSc (Hons) 2025-26

BIOS104
Notes
Changes to cycle 2 (exam) assessment to meet changes in school policy. Removal of short answer questions and replacement with MCQs

Overview

Overview
Oikos is the Greek word meaning ‘the place in which we live’. Ecology, derived from this, is the study of the place in which we live, our natural environment. Ecological questions include understanding the pattern of where organisms are in space and time, how they disperse or move, the ways in which populations go up and down in size, how different species affect each other, how communities assemble over time, and how different ecosystems form and function. Evolutionary ecology is the study of why species have come to vary in biology in this natural environment context through the process of adaptation - why some animals live fast and die young, why some plants live for a year and others for 5000. In this course we will introduce our natural environment from why species vary in fundamental characteristics such as age at maturity and offspring production, to the threats facing natural populations and ecosystems on our changing planet.

The module will be delivered through research connected interactive lectures, from leading academic researchers based at the University of Liverpool. The two module assessments are designed to help students interpret scientific publications and online tests examine student knowledge and understanding of the topics they cover.
Educational Aims
Introduce how the approach of evolutionary ecology can help us understand how and why plant and animal species differ in movement patterns, dispersal, life history and dynamics

Introduce population ecology and the diversity and importance of interspecific interactions in the dynamics and evolution of populations and communities, including the importance of microbes in community function.

Establish the main ecosystems on earth and drivers of ecosystem diversity, and an understanding of the current challenges facing biodiversity and how we might address them on a global scale.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Ecology explores the intricacies of our living environment, encompassing the spatial and temporal distribution of organisms, their dispersal patterns, population dynamics, interspecies interactions, community development over time, and the formation and functioning of diverse ecosystems. Evolutionary ecology explores the biological variations among species within this natural context, examining phenomena like rapid life cycles or long lifespans. This course provides a comprehensive overview of both foundational ecology and evolutionary ecology, addressing the challenges that natural populations and ecosystems face in our dynamic world.

The module will be delivered through, research-connected lectures by research active scientists. There are two assessments which assess students in interpreting scientific publications, while online tests assess their grasp of the covered topics. These assessments collectively contribute to evaluating students' knowledge and understanding of the subject matter.
Outline Syllabus
1. Evolutionary ecology of the pace of life, including metabolic rate, body size, age at maturity, reproductive output/timing, senescence, and ageing.

2. Evolutionary ecology of spatial patterns: dispersal biology, landscape effects, migration, and social living.

3. Population growth and dynamics, including intraspecific competition. Problems of small populations.

4. The diversity, importance, ecological and evolutionary impacts of interspecific interactions.

5. Introduction to community ecology, including succession and microbial contribution to communities.

6. The major ecosystems and drivers of ecosystem diversity. Human impacts on ecosystems.

7. Threats to populations, communities and ecosystems and conservation practice.

Material will be taxonomically broad, and include microbial, plant and animal case studies wherever possible. Basic mathematical underpinnings to be outlined in principle. Interpreting ecological data is a key element of each element, as are the citizenship aspects of ecological understanding. Supporting material (for example papers) will be supplied on CANVAS, and the course will reference the core year 1 Biology text.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

Online Preparatory Material:

This is the form of online reading, videos, and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming lectures delivered through the VLE.

Lectures:

The module will be taught through lectures with a strong element of student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a four week period.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Independent learning time (120 hours) encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

A typical week would involve 6/7 teaching sessions; sessions would vary from lectures with embedded short exercises to sessions with a series of cases studies examined and commented on in student-led discussion, using polleverywhere and other means of engagement. These student-led elements would particularly focus elements such as global citizenship and ethical aspects of ecology that are strongly motivating for engagement. Each session would be supported by external reading, and a series of case studies/problems to solve, particularly involving data.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests requires students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.

Summative assessment

There are two assessments:

a) Mid-module assessment: Mixed Multiple choice and Matching answer questions covering the material covered in the first 14 contact sessions, including questions relating to data. (30% total)

b) End of module assessment with Multiple choice questions (70% total). A fraction of these are expected to include data interpretation. Questions will be biased to the final elements of the course (70% of questions from the second half of the course).

The data interpretation aspect of the assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will use the same format, but the questions and data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity exists.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE (Virtual Learning Environment) and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Material will be taxonomically broad, and include microbial, plant and animal case studies wherever possible. Basic mathematical underpinnings to be outlined in principle. Interpreting ecological data is a key element of each element, as are the citizenship aspects of ecological understanding. Supporting material (for example papers) will be supplied on CANVAS, and the course will reference the core year 1 Biology text.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching methods used are:

Online Preparatory Material:

This is the form of online reading, videos, and small tasks to introduce key concepts for the theme and prepares students for the upcoming lectures delivered through the VLE.

Lectures:

The module will be taught through lectures with a strong element of student participation. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour Teaching Sessions will be delivered over a four week period.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Independent learning time (120 hours) encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of virtual models, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

A typical week would involve 6/7 teaching sessions; sessions would vary from lectures with embedded short exercises to sessions with a series of cases studies examined and commented on in student-led discussion, using polleverywhere and other means of engagement. These student-led elements would particularly focus elements such as global citizenship and ethical aspects of ecology that are strongly motivating for engagement. Each session would be supported by external reading, and a series of case studies/problems to solve, particularly involving data.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere) and collaborative, interactive tools for example Padlet. Formative exercises will provide students with regular feedback on their learning.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests requires students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms and ecosystems are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality, and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities and those in the global south.

Attendance Record: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Formative assessments throughout the course.

Summative assessment

There are two assessments:

a) Mid-module assessment: Mixed Multiple choice and Matching answer questions covering the material covered in the first 14 contact sessions, including questions relating to data. (30% total)

b) End of module assessment with Multiple choice questions (70% total). A fraction of these are expected to include data interpretation. Questions will be biased to the final elements of the course (70% of questions from the second half of the course).

The data interpretation aspect of the assessment is highly authentic and research-connected, and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. (Active learning, digital fluency, confidence - Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Reassessment will use the same format, but the questions and data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Resit opportunity exists.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE (Virtual Learning Environment) and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Examine the causes and consequences of variation in pace of life/life history observed between species in nature.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO2 Relate factors that impact population size and understand extinction threats arising from small populations.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO3 Explain the ways different species interact with each other and the consequences of these interactions for population size and persistence, and for evolution.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO4 Relate how ecological communities assemble and change over time.
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
 LO5 Discuss the major ecosystems in nature, their physical properties, and biological/geographical underpinnings, and how they change through time and through human activity, and describe the major threats to these
University of Liverpool · Semester 2
